contextId.information: This is an idiom that means to say to oneself or to think to oneself. AT: "A foolish person says to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: A fool says in his heart

contextId.information: Here "test my heart" means to examine my thoughts and motives. AT: "If you examine my thoughts in the night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: If you test my heart, if you come to me in the night

contextId.information: This idiom refers to those who are proud. AT: "who are proud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means the Psalmist has defeated his enemies. AT: "I have defeated all of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: they have fallen under my feet

contextId.information: This refers to those who oppose the Psalmist. AT: "those who are my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: those who rise up against me

contextId.information: This idiom pictures the servant as being removed from the sins he does not wish to commit. AT: "Also, protect your servant from doing" or "Also, make sure that I do not commit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "call to mind" is a way of saying "remember." It does not mean God forgot. It means to consider or think about. AT: "May he remember" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "have been thrown on" is a way of saying that Yahweh has taken care of him as if Yahweh had adopted him as his own child. This can be stated in active form. AT: "It was as though you had adopted me right when I was born" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: I have been thrown on you from the womb

contextId.information: Here a cup of wine that overflows represents many blessings. AT: "You fill my cup so much that it overflows" or "You give me many blessings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"rejoice in triumph over me." The phrase "over me" implies that his enemies have defeated him and stand above in victory. AT: "defeat me and rejoice about it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. This does not mean God forgot something. The writer is asking God to think about and consider his acts of compassion and faithfulness. AT: "Remember" or "Think about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to being alive. AT: "while I am alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in the land of the living

contextId.information: The phrase "sons  of" is a way of saying "having the characteristics of." AT: "you mighty men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "when you stopped helping me" or "when you rejected me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means to kill someone. AT: "kill me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "pay back" is an idiom that refers to punishment. AT: "he gives the proud people all of the punishment that they deserve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: he pays back the arrogant in full

contextId.information: Here "in Yahweh" refers to what Yahweh has done for them. "Be glad because of what Yahweh has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "in Yahweh" refers to what Yahweh has done for them. "Rejoice because of what Yahweh has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "help us." AT: "work for our good" or "help us" or "protect us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom refers to their appearance as being joyful. AT: "are joyful" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "heard" means that Yahweh helped him. AT: "Yahweh heard me" or "Yahweh helped him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "is close" means "ready to help." AT: "Yahweh is always ready to help" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means they testify in a trial. AT: "volunteer to give a testimony" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means they came together for the purpose of attacking the writer. AT: "to make plans against me" or "to plan my destruction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means to say to oneself. AT: "say to themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "give your ways" is an idiom that means to ask Yahweh to control your life. AT: "Ask Yahweh to guide your actions in life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

To "watch over" means to protect someone. Here "the blameless" refers to the blameless people. AT: "protects the blameless people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This phrase refers to disasters, such as famine. AT: "when calamities occur" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means his heart beats intensely. AT: "My heart beats loudly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "watch" is an idiom that mean "pay attention to." AT: "I will pay attention to the things that I say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will watch what I say

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "he says meaningless things" or 2) his enemies say things to make him think that they are his friends when they are not. AT: "he says deceitful things" or "they pretend to be concerned about me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The word "ears" adds emphasis to the statement that they have heard and understood the things that the writer is about to describe. The writer addresses this statement to God. AT: "God, we have heard clearly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: We have heard with our ears, God

contextId.information: This is an idiomatic expression that means everywhere in the word. AT: "everywhere in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: to the ends of the earth

contextId.information: Here the word "know" implies ownership. AT: "I own all the birds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Possible meanings are 1) that they approve of the thief's actions. AT: "you approve or him" or 2) that they join the thief in their actions. AT: "you join him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
God speaks of listing all of the evil things that they have done. AT: "list ... all the things you have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: bring up ... all the things you have done

contextId.information: Here, to be "before your eyes" means that it is in a place where they can see. This means that they will not be able to deny the charges that God brings against them. AT: "right in front of you" or "so that you can not deny them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
David's enemies are in hiding and are waiting quietly for the time when they can attack him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: they wait in ambush to take my life

contextId.information: Here "fix your heart" is an idiom that means to desire something greatly. AT: "do not desire them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: do not fix your heart on them

contextId.information: This idiom means that the writer's zeal for the temple takes over all of his thoughts and actions. AT: "completely controls all that I think and do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means "kill me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"May the king live a long time!" or "I desire that the king live a long time!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"May people always know about him" or "May people never forget who he is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "They said to themselves" or "They thought to themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Pay attention to." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:074:001|74:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "He cuts off the spirit" is an idiom that means He breaks the spirit or He humbles. AT: "He humbles the princes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: He cuts off the spirit of the princes

contextId.information: This is an idiom for remembering. AT: "I remembered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"remember" See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:074:001|74:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"remembered." See how "call to mind" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:020:003|20:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"He brought hail" or "He caused hail to fall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Possible meanings are 1) he settled Israel in their own tents in the land or 2) he settled Israel in the tents from which he had driven the other nations. Most of these "tents" were actually houses, both when the other nations lived in them and when the Israelites lived in them. AT: "in their homes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"we are very weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "stir up" means to "put into action." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
When a man in Israel wanted to honor another man, he would have that other man stand at his right side, close to his right hand. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a way of saying they get stronger. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: They go from strength to strength

contextId.information: Here "raised up" means appointed. It is implied that God chose this person to be king. AT: "I have chosen one from among the people to be king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I have raised up one chosen from among the people

contextId.information: This is a way of saying God made the king seem old even while he was still young. AT: "Even while he is young you have made him weak like an old man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: You have shortened the days of his youth

contextId.information: This is an idiom which means "kill them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Be glad because of what Yahweh has done for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"remembers." See how "call to mind" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:020:003|20:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that David would allow those people to be around him and live with him. AT: "I will allow the faithful of the land to live with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will look to the faithful of the land to sit at my side

contextId.information: This refers to his Spirit being sent to give life to creatures. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: When you send out your Spirit

contextId.information: To "seek Yahweh's strength" means to ask him to strengthen you. AT: "(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "call to mind" means to remember something. AT: "he remembers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"He sent." This means that caused a famine to happen in the land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "call to mind" means to remember something. AT: "remember me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "call to mind" means to remember something. AT: "remembered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "his days" refers to the length of his life. AT: "May he not live a long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a request for Yahweh to treat him kindly. AT: "treat me kindly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "my right hand" refers to the place of honor. AT: "Sit at the place of honor which I have for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

When the lord goes to battle, Yahweh stands at his right hand in order to help him. AT: "The Lord helps you in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The Lord is at your right hand

contextId.information: "a sincere heart." A person who is sincere will do what is right. The heart refers to the center of emotions in a person.  See how you translated "uprightness" in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:025:020|25:21]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom. The heart refers to all of one's emotions, feelings, desires, and will. AT: "with all my being" or "with everything in me" or "sincerely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. Possible meanings are that 1) he thought that he would die soon, or 2) he lay in the dust because he was very sad, or 3) he realized that he desired the worthless things of the earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: My life clings to the dust

contextId.information: This is an idiom.  Here "see" refers to being aware of the situation. The focus is on knowledge or understanding, rather than just observing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom which means to honor, cherish or respect God's commandments. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom. Anger is expressed as if it is a person that can grab another person. AT: "I have become very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Hot anger has taken hold of me

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means the writer's life is always in danger. AT: "My enemies are often trying to kill me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: My life is always in my hand

contextId.information: This is an idiom. The phrase is an exaggeration and is hyperbole for "I am extremely angry." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is an idiom. In Hebrew culture, the night was usually divided into three "watches" or periods. AT: "I am awake all night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: My eyes are open before the night watches change

contextId.information: This is an idiom. Bread often represents the food a person needs every day in order to live. AT: "work hard for your daily needs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: eat the bread of hard work

contextId.information: "All the leaders in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: All the kings of the earth

contextId.information: The psalmist uses these two actions to represent everything he does. AT: "everything I do" or  "everything about me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]]) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
contextId.quote: when I sit down and when I get up

contextId.information: "they are uncountable" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: they would be more in number than the sand

contextId.information: those who speak evil of others without cause (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"while I am living" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in the land of the living

contextId.information: "Please do not judge" or "I beg you not to judge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"praise him with songs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
